awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 2: Collaborative Research: Improving High-Impact Hail Event Forecasts by Linking Hail Environments and Modeled Hailstorm Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States suffers billions of dollars in insured losses each year from damaging hail storms and the societal and economic costs of such storms have been increasing. Over 10 million properties in the U.S. were damaged by hail in 2017 alone. Recent examples of catastrophic hailstorms include a $2.3 billion loss hail event impacting Denver in 2017, a $1.4 billion loss hail event in San Antonio in April 2016 that included 4.5+ inch hailstones, and a 2012 hailstorm in Amarillo, TX that produced 2-m drifts of hail that washed out roads and brought traffic to a standstill. Unfortunately, none of these events were anticipated ahead of time. This proposal will identify what type of environments produce such high impact hail events, and how the physical processes that produce hail are affected by environmental processes. The improved understanding of hail growth will be incorporated into a hail forecasting system within national weather prediction models to improve hail forecasts, which is in line with NSF's mission to advance national health, prosperity and welfare and to secure the national defense. With improved short-term (< 1 h) hail forecasts, immediate threats could be avoided, such as recommending that attendees at outdoor stadiums or events take shelter. Improved intermediate-term forecasts (1-3 days) could result in recommended action that required more time-intensive planning, such as moving aircraft under shelter, notifying insurance adjusters, and working with county-level emergency managers to have contingency plans in place for public outdoor events. Knowledge of the expected type of event, such as giant hail or lots of small hail (or "blizzard" hail), in addition to merely hail size, would allow forecasters to better prepare the public: for example, a forecasted "blizzard" hail event might require a city to ready its plowing equipment and advise the public to avoid low-lying areas that could potentially flood. Additionally, knowledge of which environments are connected to which hail events types is a necessary step for developing hail forecasts on longer time scales, of subseasonal to seasonal scale and beyond. This proposal will also support a graduate student receiving a Ph.D. degree, two graduate students receiving M.S. degrees, and three undergraduate students.

In order to advance predictability and reduce the increasingly significant impact of hail on society, this proposal will accomplish the following four goals: 
1) Identify environmental controls on hail production for different hail threat classes (e.g., giant hail or >10 cm or 4 in, large amounts of small hail) and identify regime, seasonal and regional differences.
2) Establish the physical relationship between hail threat class occurrence and environmental conditions. Determine what embryo source region characteristics increase the probability of favorable hail growth trajectories for different classes of hail threats and how these vary across realistic storm environments.
3) Validate a microphysically complex hail trajectory model in light of newly available time-varying radar-retrieved wind and buoyancy fields and surface hail observations.
4) Integrate new knowledge about environmental controls, three-dimensional hail trajectories, and embryo source regions into the CAM-HAILCAST hail model to improve operational forecasts of hail threats.
Objective 1 will use an extensive hailstorm proximity sounding database available from the Storm Prediction Center (SPC) to explore environmental controls. Objective 2 will use idealized simulations to explore sensitivity to both environmental conditions and microphysical processes. Objective 3 will use a newly-developed radar-derived wind and microphysical dataset to drive a hail trajectory model which will be validated with surface hail observations. Finally, the improved hail forecasting model developed in Objective 4 will be tested against an independent subset of hail threat events from the SPC database. This proposed research will improve understanding of the basic processes underlying hail growth on both environmental- and storm-scales and how those vary across environments. It will determine which environments are most favorable to different hail threat classes (such as giant hail or large amounts of small hail) or hail sizes. It also moves beyond a purely statistical endeavor to ensure the physical processes underlying the environmental controls for each hail threat class are understood, including large updraft volumes, favorable placement of embryo source regions, and appropriate embryo sizes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hailstorms are incredibly damaging phenomena in the United States and worldwide, producing tens of billion dollars in insured losses per year to property. This project produced critical insights into how we predict the environments that produce large hailstones. Surprisingly, the conditions that result in hail were previously poorly understood, and lacked strong statistical evidence that they were effective. The main goal of this project was to identify how the nearby environmental conditions of the storm influence hail production for different hail sizes and ascertain whether there were different weather patterns that caused these events, or seasonal and regional differences.

To address our limited understanding, we developed a new hail environment dataset comprised of over 110,000 quality-controlled cases with hail sizes from 0.25-8 inches in diameter and in doing so revealed significant dataset limitations in past approaches that have made this problem more challenging than it should have been. Using these data, we explored a range of environmental conditions and their relationship to hail, identifying that many of the variables we use to describe the atmosphere appear to have limited use when applied to hail. To address this, we used vertical profiles of the atmosphere near to observed hail events to explore how these features were related to hailstorms. We found that there are significant differences between the profiles that produce hail and those that produce tornadoes, however predicting hail size based on wind profiles alone is not likely to be successful.

This led us to explore a new approach where we separated the dataset into regimes of similar large scale weather patterns using the characteristics of the profile, which included its potential to produce a strong updraft, moisture, and the underlying wind field. This yielded appreciable insight into why predicting hail has been challenging, in that regardless of location or season, there are multiple types of weather patterns that tend to produce hail. Sometimes these regimes favor large hail events, while other regimes favor smaller hail. From this we were able to ascertain that skill for prediction for previous operationally used parameters is not always low, but rather, reflect our skill of predicting these events in just a few of these weather regimes. This has implications for developing new forecasting parameters and suggests a flexible approach is necessary. Specifically, the approach needs to not be one size fits all, and needs  to include these favorable weather patterns, a problem which is ideally suited to emerging techniques in machine learning such as random forests to encompass these possibilities.

Once this need was identified, a variety of new parameters were tested, with promising results for the vertical distribution of energy to support thunderstorm updrafts, the lowest 4 km winds relative to the storm, the presence of convective inhibition, the potential for entrainment, a deeper measure of environmental change of temperature (lapse rate) through the 2-6km layer, and moisture content in the midlevel of the storm (approximately 2-4 km above the ground). Testing these new parameters corroborated modeling results that showed a balance between the potential for strong updrafts and the wind profile was more favorable for larger hail. Through use of these newly developed parameters, and the weather pattern aware approach, we were able to develop a more skillful predictive model for whether smaller or large hail should be expected.

Finally, we also explored the near-storm conditions for the largest hail sizes (those greater than 3 inches), finding that there appears to be less hope for characterizing the predictability of these events. This is not to say that we cannot predict days that will favor larger hail sizes (greater than 2 inches), but rather predicting specific sizes beyond this becomes more challenging (though we note that most hail of at least 2 inches in diameter is extremely damaging). This is because in many cases there are complex storm interactions with external features such as boundaries, other storms or convective systems that interact with storms, and such outcomes are inherently chaotic and challenging to predict. This complements by research by our collaborators which shows similar challenges in predictability can arise from internal storm scale processes.

These results have been shared with both the global severe storms community as well as the operational forecaster community in the United States. They are also informing the development of new predictors, and improve our capacity to model and forecast hail size, an important and impactful natural hazard. These improvements to prediction can help contribute to improved mitigation of hail losses. This project also supported a PhD student at Central Michigan University, along with first time research opportunities for four undergraduate students. Each of these students has gone on to graduate study.
